title: Letters from Thomas Percy, D.D. :
snippet: ■ This seems to have been some communication to the Society: of Antiquaries, probably relative to the wanton dilapidation of Dunfermline Abbey, which is in the immediate vicinity of Mr Chalmers's estate of Pittencrieff; and this supposition is confirmed by the ensuing passage from a letter to Paton.

title: [Works]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Then she told us to fall to, and there would be no more to pay ; for the inn was her own, or at least her father's, and he was gone for the day to Pittencrieff.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: Arthur, the eldest, laird of Pittencrieff and a colonel in the Dutch service, was a man of infinite humour, which consisted much in his instantaneous and lively invention of fictions and tales to illustrate or ridicule the conversation  that was going on ; and as his tales were inoffensive,  though totally void of truth, they afforded great amusement to every company.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: Among them are the portraits by Raeburn ofGeorge Chalmers of Pittencrieff and Provost Low of Fordel,one by Sir Francis Grant of James 8th Earl of Elgin,who was successively Governor-General of Jamaica, Canada,and India, and Plenipotentiary to China; and a fourthportrait by Lawrence of Admiral Sir Andrew Mitchell.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: It was, however,now generally agreed that the name was derived from thecastle of King Malcolm Canmore, a fragment of whichbuilding was still to be seen upon the steep ground known asTowerhill, in the policies of the estate of Pittencrieff, in theimmediate vicinity of the Abbey and Palace.
